questions.question: Should Hello World support multiple projects or just one at a time?
questions.context: Currently the app is pointed at a single project path. Multi-project support would require a project switcher UI and separate data stores per project.
questions.answer: One project at a time for now. The setup screen already handles project selection. Multi-project can come later if there's demand.

questions.question: Should we add keyboard shortcuts to the Hello World desktop app?
questions.context: Currently everything is mouse-driven. Power users might want hotkeys to switch views or trigger actions.
questions.answer: Yes â€” basic view-switching shortcuts (1-8 for each view) would be a quick win. Low effort, high power-user appeal.

questions.question: Should the Settings view allow changing the project path without reinstalling?
questions.context: Currently project path is set once on first launch. Changing it requires manual config edits.
questions.answer: Yes -- this is now part of the multi-project support epic. A proper project switcher will replace the current one-time setup. Settings will include project management.

questions.question: Verification test question -- does the question system work?
questions.answer: Yes, it works. Verified during feature verification run.

questions.question: Should buddy recap use AI summarization (via Claude Haiku API call in detached subprocess) or simple bullet-point extraction from activity.json?
questions.context: Decision d_buddy_recap chose hybrid approach: rolling buffer (crash-safe) + AI summary on clean exit. But the AI summary requires an API call from a detached Node subprocess. Alternative: just extract last 5-8 activity entries and format as bullets. Simpler, no API cost, but less polished.

questions.question: Should we adopt Spec-Driven Development workflow using cc-sdd or OpenSpec?
questions.context: Research found 6+ tools. Best fits: cc-sdd (Kiro-compatible, 13 languages, one npx command) or OpenSpec (25.8k stars, lightweight, fluid iteration). Both add slash commands to .claude/commands/. The workflow: research -> spec -> plan -> tasks -> implement. Would replace our current ad-hoc task creation with structured specs. Could complement our existing deliberation system. Trade-off: more upfront overhead per feature, but less rework and better crash recovery (specs survive context loss).

questions.question: Is Hello World a personal tool or a product? If product, what's the go-to-market?
questions.context: Hello World is currently Pat's personal AI workspace. Multi-project support is in scope. But is the goal to ship this to other Claude Code users? If so, the target market is AI-native developers who want an autonomous workspace with persistent memory, deliberation, and project management. Competitors: Cursor, Windsurf, Cline, Continue. Differentiator: the autonomous workflow engine (tasks, approvals, deliberation, memory) that no IDE has. Revenue model: open source core + paid cloud sync / team features? Needs Pat's input on ambition level.

questions.question: Should the three DELIBERATE tasks (memory quality, knowledge intake, state storage) be run as full deliberations or converted to regular implementation tasks?
questions.context: Three tasks tagged [DELIBERATE]: (1) Memory quality feedback loop (t_e215a18e), (2) Knowledge intake scheduling (t_fee42a1a), (3) State storage JSON vs SQLite (t_f2d9ad7d). State storage was already decided (d_a9d3b3d7: split files + atomic writes, defer SQLite). Memory quality and knowledge intake could be implemented with a lightweight design pass instead of full deliberation, since the system is already functional and iterating fast. Full deliberation adds overhead (plan + approval + agents + coverage + conclude). Trade-off: thoroughness vs. velocity.
